docs.lead_paragraph: Genetically engineered mice have helped prove that about 50 people with a rare brain illness caught it by eating beef from cattle with so-called mad cow disease, researchers said today. In a study conducted by scientists at the University of California at San Francisco and Western General Hospital in Edinburgh, Scotland, the mice became ill in exactly the same way when they were injected with diseased material from cattle and humans who had died of the illness.

headline.main: Beef Consumption Tied to Mad Cow Disease

docs.abstract: Researchers say that genetically engineered mice have helped prove that about 50 people with rare brain illness caught it by eating beef from cattle with so-called mad cow disease; scientists say finding provides very strong evidence that bovine spongiform encephalopathy (mad cow disease) and new form of its human cousin, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, are the same (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Some elderly people who are given diagnoses of voice or speech disorders may simply be showing ordinary signs of aging, scientists say. A study of 44 men and women aged 70 to 80 detected numerous changes in their speaking voices.

headline.main: When Specialists Err on Aging Voices

docs.abstract: Scientists say that some elderly people who are given diagnoses of voice or speech disorders may simply be showing ordinary signs of aging (S)
docs.snippet: Some elderly people who are given diagnoses of voice or speech disorders may simply be showing ordinary signs of aging, scientists say.    A study of 44 men and women aged 70 to 80 detected numerous changes in their speaking voices.

docs.lead_paragraph: Barbie is about to become environmentally correct. Her creator, Mattel Inc., the world's largest toy maker, announced this month that it would begin an effort to eliminate petroleum-based plastics, which have been linked to an assortment of environmental and health problems, from its most popular doll and many of its other toys. Environmental and consumer groups say the announcement marks a significant break with industry practice. ''It is a major move, and other manufacturers are going to have to follow,'' said Rick Hind, legislative director of the environmental group Greenpeace.

headline.main: Barbie and Other Toys to Go on an Oil-Free Diet

docs.abstract: Mattel Inc, world's largest toy maker, will try to eliminate petroleum-based plastics, which have been linked to assortment of environmental and health problems, from its popular Barbie doll and many of its other toys; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gay men are almost twice as likely to smoke cigarettes as men over all, a new study finds. The study, by researchers at the University of California at San Francisco, looked at 2,600 men who described themselves as gay or bisexual. About 48 percent reported smoking, compared with about 27 percent of all American men.
docs.abstract: New study finds that gay men are almost twice as likely to smoke cigarettes as men over all (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lurking in the guts of many pets and people is a sneaky parasite that may well be the most common cause of gastrointestinal distress in this and many other countries. The organism, a protozoan called giardia (pronounced jee-AR-dee-ya), is easy to acquire but hard to diagnose and often difficult to treat effectively. It can cause no symptoms at all or it can turn its host into one sick puppy suffering from abdominal cramps, diarrhea and weight loss. It may even result in food allergies. In its various forms, giardia can infect most vertebrates, but one form, Giardia lamblia, has a particular penchant for mammals, including dogs, cats, livestock and people.

headline.main: Sly Parasite Menaces Pets and Their Owners

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on giardia, giardia that lurks in guts of many pets and people and may well be most common cause of gastrointestinal distress in United States and many other countries (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Buying contact lenses has never been easier. Besides the traditional outlets, like optometrists' offices and mail order stores, they can be found on hundreds of Web sites and even at beauty salons and local flea markets. But while this explosion of suppliers has held down prices, it has created a problem, in the view of eye doctors, school nurses and contact lens manufacturers: growing numbers of people are getting contact lenses illegally, without prescriptions, and they are suffering from health problems as a result.

headline.main: Online Lens Sales Raise Health Concerns

docs.abstract: Eye doctors, school nurses and contact lens manufacturers say that growing numbers of people are getting contact lenses illegally, without prescriptions, and they are suffering from health problems as result; buying contact lenses has never been easier; besides traditional outlets, like optometrists' offices and mail order stores, they can be found on hundreds of Web sites and even at beauty salons and local flea markets (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Terry Hoddinot, 36, of London, Ontario, has been blind since the age of 3. His son, Riley, 3 1/2, lost his left eye a month ago. And the same rare eye cancer, retinoblastoma, was diagnosed in his baby daughter, Katie, while she was still in the womb. But doctors say there is a good chance that they may have saved Katie's vision with a bold new procedure: delivering her prematurely, then treating the affected eye before the cancer had a chance to grow and blind her.

headline.main: Attacking Eye Cancer Early (in the Womb)

docs.abstract: Bold new procedure for attacking retinoblastoma, a rare eye cancer that is diagnosed while child is still in womb, entails delivering baby prematurely, then treating affected eye before cancer has chance to grow and cause blindness; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With relatively basic eye examination, vision loss among people with diabetes can often be prevented -- a point that frustrates experts in the field. About half of the nation's 16 million diabetics develop at least some retinopathy, which damages the small blood vessels in the retina. But it cannot be discerned through a regular eye exam; to see it, the examiner must dilate the retina with drops. Retinopathy can be treated with laser surgery, if detected early.

headline.main: For Diabetics, a Sight-Saving Eye Test

docs.abstract: New study finds that critical eye examination rates for black diabetics can be greatly improved with aggressive education program; avoidable vision loss is particularly prevalent among diabetics who are black (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: More people than ever are surviving cancer, health officials say; by one estimate, about 8.4 million Americans who have had cancer are alive today. But from this indisputable good news flows a host of new challenges for doctors and patients alike, as the survivors and their families face years of uncertainty and health concerns that few people without cancer could imagine. A newly redesigned Web site aims to make these waters easier to navigate.

headline.main: An Online Aid for Surviving Cancer

docs.abstract: Newly redesigned Web site aims to help cancer patients and their families (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: At some point this year, I noticed that I could not bend over and touch my fingertips to the ground. The combination of running the marathon, completing a century (riding 100 miles on a bicycle) and the subsequent nursing of sore knees, tight quads and stiff hips had taken its toll: what little flexibility I was born with had vanished. Last year's New Year's resolution to cut back on running and spend more time stretching went the way of most New Year's resolutions (ignored until forgotten), and the thought of struggling through an organized stretch class filled with limber-bodied budding ballerinas was too intimidating to consider.

headline.main: A Yoga Studio That Thinks It's a Sauna

docs.abstract: The Novice column on Bikram yoga, exercise class that is conducted in room heated to 100 degrees; drawings (M)
